newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel silent on TV report of secret Syria message.
newsitem.headline: Israel silent on TV report of secret Syria message.

text.p: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office declined comment on an Israeli television report on Thursday that a secret message from Syria could enable their long-stalled peace talks to resume.

A spokeswoman would not comment on the report of Channel Two television that Netanyahu's political adviser Dore Gold secretly met U.S. diplomat Edward Djerejian who was returning from a meeting with Syrian President Hafez al-Assad in Damascus.

The television report quoted senior political sources as saying five years of on-again, off-again talks between Israel and Syria might resume after U.S. elections on November 5. Djerejian is a former U.S. ambassador to Israel.

Netanyahu has insisted he is interested in making peace but Arabs are sceptical because of his opposition to swapping occupied Arab land for peace -- a foundation of their talks launched in Madrid in 1991.
Syria demands the return of all of the Golan Heights captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war. The right-wing Netanyahu, elected in May, opposes giving up any of the strategic plateau.
